abstract.text: Provides a standard user interface to allow one iOS device to discover and connect to another.

inlineContent.text: class in the Multipeer Connectivity framework instead.

platforms.message: Use MCBrowserViewController from the MultipeerConnectivity framework.
platforms.name: visionOS

inlineContent.text: object connecting the two devices. To use a

object, your application creates the controller, adds a delegate, configures the allowed connection types, and then shows the peer picker. The delegate is called as the user makes selections within the peer picker interface.
In iOS 3.0, the peer picker can be configured to select between Bluetooth and Internet connections.
Although users can select Internet connections in the peer picker,

has no user interface for configuring them. If your application configures the peer picker to allow Internet connections, your application must also dismiss the peer picker and present its own interface to configure an Internet connection.

On iOS 3.0, your application should release the peer picker object after it dismisses the peer picker dialog. On iOS 3.1 or later, your application may release the peer picker after it is shown to the user. If you do this, the peer picker controller is automatically deallocated after the dialog is dismissed.

abstract.text: The `MCBrowserViewController` class presents nearby devices to the user and enables the user to invite nearby devices to a session. To use this class in iOS or tvOS, call methods from the underlying `UIViewController` class ([`prepare(for:sender:)`](doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/UIKit/UIViewController/prepare(for:sender:)) and [`performSegue(withIdentifier:sender:)`](doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/UIKit/UIViewController/performSegue(withIdentifier:sender:)) for storyboards or [`present(_:animated:completion:)`](doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/UIKit/UIViewController/present(_:animated:completion:)) and [`dismiss(animated:completion:)`](doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/UIKit/UIViewController/dismiss(animated:completion:)) for nib-based views) to present and dismiss the view controller. In macOS, use the comparable `NSViewController` methods [`presentAsSheet(_:)`](doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/AppKit/NSViewController/presentAsSheet(_:)) and [`dismiss(_:)`](doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/AppKit/NSViewController/dismiss(_:)-91my5) instead.
Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
An
object provides a standard user interface to display achievement progress for the local player. If the
class is available, you should use it instead.
The
class is used to respond to events related to challenges sent or received by the local player.
The object representing the currently signed-in iCloud user.
Your game uses the
class to present a screen that allows the local player to send friend requests to other players.
The dashboard that allows players to access their Game Center data in your game.
A game session you can use to save game data, invite other players, and create turn-based and real-time game apps.
A user interface you can use to invite other users into a tvOS game session.
The
class provides a standard user interface that displays leaderboard scores to the player. If the
class is available, you should use it instead.
Network connections available to the peer picker dialog.
Provides a standard user interface to allow one iOS device to discover and connect to another.
A mask that determines the types of connections a dialog presents to the user.
The delegate of the peer picker controller.
Hides the peer picker dialog.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the picker dialog is visible.
Displays the peer picker dialog to the user.
An object containing information for a score that was earned by the player.
A
object provides the ability to discover and connect to nearby iOS devices using Bluetooth or Wi-fi.
The
class is used to respond to important messages related to turn-based matches. To use it, call the
class method to get the singleton instance and assign an object that implements the
protocol to its
property. All methods are called on the main thread.
The delegate for the event handler.
Returns the shared instance of the event handler.
The
protocol is implemented by an object to receive notifications events for turn-based matches. All methods are called on the main thread.
A voice channel that allows players to speak with each other in a multiplayer game.
The
class allows your application to connect two iOS devices into a voice chat.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
